content: @nagisa I was going to ask, do you want to run meeting today or shall I?
but I guess maybe that answers my question

I didn't have internet connectivity until a few minutes ago (silly cafe) so I'm not going to be able to get nearly as much done as @pnkfelix, but I'll at least get a head-start on triaging the P-high issues.
# matching against an associated constant gives type error #57280 -- pending PR
# rustdoc crashing on linux-sparc64 due to unaligned access #56927 -- fixed by @Nikita Popov, but we need a beta backport still
@nikomatsakis I can run, and I do have a prepass in my notepad.
# PhantomData fields in repr(C) structs change ABI on aarch64 #56877 -- currently assigned to @pnkfelix, but not progress as far as I know. We might want to find someone else.
oh, ok I'll just stop :)
Its almost time for the meeting anyway
yeah :)
Hi, @T-compiler!
(@T-compiler/meeting)

# matching against an associated constant gives type error #57280 -- pending PR

@nikomatsakis has a [zulip log] in their last comment but no corresponding [zulip log]:.
I just submitted a PR that fixes this.
Ah yeah, you said that. :face_palm:
Yeah, niko already noted that there is a pending PR.
I’ll leave off all P-highs assigned to pnkfelix for last P-highs, as they are absent till probably mid-January?
So going through what @nikomatsakis already looked at...

• rustdoc crashing on linux-sparc64 due to unaligned access #56927

Tracking beta-backport of #57053, which is beta-nominated, we’ll get to that later.

• PhantomData fields in repr(C) structs change ABI on aarch64 #56877

There has been a fair amount of discussion, but it does not seem like a proper strategy has been formed yet…
I am wondering if we should reassign
although I would guess @pnkfelix will be back around probably next week
If any of you have any good ideas on how and what to filter and how to consider what is ABI-relevant and what is not, a note on PR would be great.
but they don't seem like an obvious candidate, more like @eddyb

although I would guess @pnkfelix will be back around probably next week

er actually I think that's wrong
mid-January according to their own words.
right
@nagisa maybe reassign to me and I'll try to sketch out some suggestions
Okay, moving on (as I write up a note on strategy to the issue discussed above)

• figure out how to integrate constants and the MIR type checker #46702

Has been discussed at NLL workgroup meeting, assigned to @nikomatsakis for investigation.
yeah that's fine, I'll try to get to that too :)
Okay. Next is...

• Compiler panics unexpectedly in 1.31 when constructing struct with wrong syntax #56611

Left open to figure if #56850 needs to be backported and if so, how. #56850 is beta-accepted.
@Alexander Regueiro is it fine to assign to you to prepare a backport?
(you’re already an assignee)
I’ll write a note on the PR, I guess.

• Nightly: thread '<unnamed>' panicked at 'couldn't compile the test', src/librustdoc/test.rs:326:13 #56867

Haven’t touched it since the first look. It still bothers me that there are two issues mashed into one here. I could not reproduce the originally reported one. The crossbeam one is reproducible and has been bisected. The PR seems relevant, but without more investigation it is not clear whom to blame – crossbeam for assuming too much or the PR.
I guess I’ll ask to fill a separate issue for crossbeam

• [nll] move 2-phase borrows into MIR lowering #53198

As one would be expected, holidays masterfully prevented any(?) activity here.
( I'm going to assign myself to that and try to push that ball forward in @pnkfelix's absence )

• regression: stack overflow on macosx with xcode 6.4 #55471

The PR that was a root cause of this to happen has been reverted. This is now a regression from stable-to-stable, so an opportunity for a timely backport seems to have been missed. Long term fix #55617 based on stacker has not been merged. Current strategy in the PR only works on Tier1 platforms only, but I have made a crate over the holidays that supports most of the architectures and have made a PR against stacker to use it.
So the progress is smooth here.
Assuming @Alex Crichton agrees to merge my PR against stacker.

Two more NLL issues are:

  • [nll] _ patterns should not count as borrows #53114
  • NLL / MIR-borrowck regression in getopts #48225

but I struggled to write up any summary for either of them, so there isn’t any
I think that #48225 is likely "not a bug"
not sure about #53114, I'll revisit (looks like tomorrow will be an NLL catch up day )
and/or sync up with @Matthew Jasper
@nikomatsakis do you want to reassign both to yourself?
Also it would be nice to remove the I-nominated from #48225

do you want to reassign both to yourself?

will do

Then after that there also are two more issues assigned to @pnkfelix:

  • prohibit "two-phase borrows" with existing borrows? #56254
  • two-phase-borrows need a specification #46901
These have likely seen no activity/progress.
The specification issue seems a broad documentation one, which does not seem to block any particular release
those are both kind of the same as the other 2PB issues
but will probably impede work on NLL.
that is, the "rewrite one"
well, at least the first one
so I'll assign that to myself
I guess it already is
the #46901 .. yeah, let's leave that, I don't foresee having time for writing specs in the next week, but I think it's a good question how we will coordinate to make it happen
(rust all-hands seems like a great time to brainstorm the coordination :slight_smile:)
Right, so that’s it for the P-high issues.

# beta-nominated

5 PRs to look at.
• Wf-check the output type of a function in MIR-typeck #57282
(I made emojis you can click on, :back: is for backport, :not_allowed: is for not backport)
the main question is: do we not backport because this already made it to stable? I feel like we might as well close the hole as soon as possible though.
this seems like a fairly serious issue to me
It's a very small patch and a high-priority issue. Makes sense to backport to me even if it's already hit stable.
I would perhaps even lean towards backporting to stable, but a new stable is coming out fairly soon already.
so there is little value in doing that.
yeah, I don't think it's worth it.
sounds like we should backport

Next in the queue is:

  • resolve: Fix one more ICE in import validation #57185
The PR is mostly tests.
looks pretty harmless
How do we know which way you vote @nagisa since you need to click on both options?
@davidtwco I end up removing the other vote once I get to the next ticket.
So it appears to not have been confirmed that the issue is a regression at all
Ah the issue says this is a stable-to-stable regression
seems like a similar situation to the one before
i.e., problem discovered from Rust 2018
Right, except the bug this fixes is not as critical.
@nagisa I’m pretty sure that was already backported no?
To beta at least

@nagisa I’m pretty sure that was already backported no?

Are you talking about the #56850? Could you find the ticket with the backport?
Seems like the consensus is to backport the PR at hand.
I think this is the backport https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/57236
I don’t know it sorry. The release team closed my backport PR ages ago, for some reason.

Next is another one from @Vadim Petrochenkov (spoiler, there is more!)

  • resolve: Fix another ICE in import validation #57181
Could test on playground though. I’m not on a computer however.
@Wesley Wiser okay, thanks, I’ll note it on the issue and close it.
:+1:🏻
So back to #57181: a small issue, mostly tests.
A 2018 regression.
just like the previous PR.
• resolve: Fix an ICE in import validation #57160
More of the same :slight_smile:
seems like this is to be expected, given that we landed such a major rewrite
Well, I admit that I didn’t participate in testing 2018 edition at all, and I suspect that this is true for most.

Final backport nomination is

  • Fix alignment for array indexing #57053

Well, I admit that I didn’t participate in testing 2018 edition at all, and I suspect that this is true for most.

well this particular rewrite landed shortly before the stable release anyway :P
now this is an interesting one as it technically solves a soundness issue
(codegen issues pertaining to alignment are classified as such, usually)
Although the worst that happens to our knowledge is that SPARC is crashing
(added emojis, click away!)
Okay, that’s it for the backports.
preparing the rollup right now

# stable-to beta regressions

5 of them. 3 T-rustdoc. 1 is a P-high that has been looked at before. Which leaves...

  • error: internal compiler error: src/librustc/ty/relate.rs:753: impossible case reached: can't relate: (T,) with Lifetime('_#1r) #57156 is the only thing to look at.
This is a fairly recently filled one, which explains lack of investiation :slight_smile:
We need a P-flag.
and possibly a volunteer to look at it.
Hmm. I can investigate that.
(Though if someone else wants to, that's fine with me too)
What priority do you reckon we give it?
P-high?
Seems like P-high
at least to bisect
ps @Pietro Albini have you ever considered a bisection bot? :)
dang but that would be cool
sure I have considered it, but I need someone to patch my clock to add a few extra hours :P
and we have too many infra nightmares right now
haha fair enough
@nikomatsakis I found cargo bisect to work fairly nice already
as long as it's on a wishlist somewhere :)
do you mean the cargo-bisect-rustc tool that @simulacrum made, @nagisa ?
being able to request it on github comments would be :star: though.
yeah.
if so, I agree it works well, which is why we are tantalizingly close to a bot :)
although it always takes me a bit to figure out how to configure it again
Okay, so that was it for the stable-to-beta regressions
@nagisa please set both the nominated and accepted labels when you accept something though

# stable-to-nightly regressions

6 of them. 1 is a P-high and has been looked at before. This is also where my notepad ends for all but two more issues.

@nagisa please set both the nominated and accepted labels when you accept something though

ah right...
/me did a blunder.
• nightly rustc --version hangs forever #56736 is the antivirus problem. There is probably no reason to discuss it again.
• Up to 7% regression in recent rollup #57115
@Alex Crichton made a PR for this, it seems.
(https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/57287)
(when you have time, could someone check if https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/56838 actually needs to be backported?)
So the issue is in good hands.
@Pietro Albini do you mean "needs" as in whether it has been backported yet or not?
it's backported, but the changed code doesn't exist on beta
should #56736 have been marked with T-infra?
@Pietro Albini you want to ask for a backport PR then, instead of doing it yourself.
@Pietro Albini and that’s T-rustdoc
@nagisa it changes only compiler files though
@varkor it is not too obvious whether it falls onto infra hands or not either
@varkor but I marked it as T-infra nevertheless
it seems good to pass the baton somewhere if it's a regression, so it can either be closed or fixed
(please also put the nomination when you tag infra, we don't check regressions on our meeting -- already did that for this)
@Pietro Albini for the backport I would then ping relevant-seeming people on the ticket (git blame perhaps helps here?)
Okay, next up is:
• ICE instead of coherence error #57162
oh wait
Here we go, fixed.
Any P-flag suggestions?
P-high
probably due to some of the recent PRs in this area
not sure who to assign it to exactly
I'd volunteer but I don't know if I will realistically have time
probably a good idea to start with a bisection
@Alexander Regueiro since you have been commenting on it, are you perhaps interested in looking into this?
I could bisect this too, this seems fairly straightforward I guess.
I’ll assign this to myself.
@nagisa cc me once you figure out the cause if you remember :)

Next up is

  • rustc 1.33.0-nightly (b2b7a063a 2019-01-01) compiler unexpectedly panics #57264
@nagisa If you can pin down the commit that introduced it, I can work on a fix if you like.
Only that build times are agonisingly long on my machine, so I don’t want to bisect!
@Taylor Cramer has identified a possible cause here.
@Taylor Cramer suspects #57264 is caused by a @Vadim Petrochenkov commit, maybe we should bisect it to be sure?
but we can also assign to @Vadim Petrochenkov I think
i'd call it P-high
(my default stance for a regression)

Only that build times are agonisingly long on my machine, so I don’t want to bisect!

(btw note that cargo-bisect-rustc downloads prebuilt binaries)
though I'm often amazed how long that takes regardless :)
I've also got the bisection thing up and going now so I can bisect #57264
That makes it all regressions.
we're about out of time looks like

Speaking of builds, @centril has suggested SSH boxes for building available to T-compiler and possibly regular regular contributors, to speed things up. I liked the idea. Not sure if Mozilla could do this for us though. Anyway, don’t want to derail the conversation really. Maybe talk about it another time.
@Alexander Regueiro there is a cool thing called GCC Farm.
it's been suggested before; would be nice to make something available
not sure what format it should take
Oh yeah? Not heard of it.
(hopefully it could be funded by more than just mozilla, too)
I wanted to call attention to the question of tomorrow's scheduled steering meeting
I posted this comment on internals -- not sure if enough people will be around or what
We could achieve a lot by just donating some compute resources to that project.
(this meeting for example seemed a bit lightly attended)
@nikomatsakis Yeah. I don’t care who funds it, but if someone or multiple ones could, would be great.
Right, so I want to call to attention that there is an ongoing FCP
ah, true, I hadn't noticed that somehow, must have missed it
That’s it. Adjourned!
but I'm excited about that PR ( :tada: @Oli)

That’s it. Adjourned!

Thanks @nagisa for running the meeting

I have an idea for a build service that infra could run given a set of computing resources... if they have the time to manage it. I might even be able to write the software for it if there’s interest. Should I make an internals thread?
@nikomatsakis Cosmetics PR on topic for next meeting, if there aren’t more important things? :-)

I have an idea for a build service that infra could run given a set of computing resources... if they have the time to manage it. I might even be able to write the software for it if there’s interest. Should I make an internals thread?

Sure! Although I strongly encourage you to play with GCC Farm as well. The accounts there are given out on-request to contributors of free (as in freedom) software, which rustc is.

@nikomatsakis Cosmetics PR on topic for next meeting, if there aren’t more important things? :-)

Yep! I was thinking that there were some nominated PRs we really should discuss, but I didn't raise it because it seemed like we didn't have that many folks anyway (plus out of time)
Given the difficulties we’re having with procuring some non-standard non-x86_64 hardware for our CI, I would not expect much success in getting ssh boxes infrastructure going on our own.
(sharing the infra with GCC farm does seem appealing, if they'd be interested -- I'd not heard of that project before)
